header.title: A Compleat System of MAGICK; OR, THE History of the BLACK-ART.
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, History of Magic

central_thesis: This work aims to provide a comprehensive historical and systematic account of 'Magick' and the 'Black-Art.' It traces their evolution from ancient natural philosophy and wisdom to later diabolical practices, elucidating the methods, figures, and perceived interactions with spirits, particularly the Devil, throughout various ages and cultures. The author distinguishes between legitimate 'Magick' (natural philosophy) and 'Black Art' (diabolical deception or human cunning), ultimately attributing malicious magical acts to either the Devil's direct influence or human artifice.

structure_content.chapter_title: INTRODUCTION. Of the Meaning of the Terms; who and what kind of People the Magicians were, and how the Words Magick or Magician were originally understood.
structure_content.summary: This section defines 'Magick' and 'Magician' in their ancient sense as referring to wise men, philosophers, and astronomers who studied nature and interpreted phenomena, contrasting this with the later, corrupted understanding of sorcery and dealing with the Devil.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. II. How Wisdom and Learning advanc'd Men in the First Ages to Royalty and Government, and How many of the Magicians were made Kings on that Account; as Zoroaster, Cadmus, and many others.
structure_content.summary: The chapter discusses how ancient 'Magi,' through their wisdom, knowledge, and contributions to society (e.g., Zoroaster, Cadmus), attained positions of power and even kingship, indicating the high esteem in which natural learning was once held.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. III. Of the Reason and Occasion which brought the ancient honest Magi, whose original Study was Philosophy, Astronomy, and the Works of Nature, to turn Sorcerers and Wizards, and deal with the Devil; and how their Conversation began.
structure_content.summary: This part explores the degeneration of 'Magick' from natural philosophy to diabolical arts, suggesting that human ambition, curiosity, and a desire for knowledge beyond natural means led to a 'long Progression of Studies' and 'wicked Schemes' that eventually drew mankind into commerce with infernal agents.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. IV. Of what Shapes the Devil assum'd in his first Appearances to the Magicians, and others, in the First Ages of the World; and whether He is, or has been, allowed to assume a human Shape, or no.
structure_content.summary: The author discusses the Devil's initial, often subtle, appearances, primarily through dreams and visions, which were used to manipulate individuals like Canaan and inspire large-scale projects like the Tower of Babel. It delves into the debate of whether the Devil can assume a human shape, suggesting he often operates invisibly or in disguised forms for strategic reasons.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. V. A Farther Account of the Devil's Conduct in Imitating Divine Inspirations; Something of the Difference between them; and particularly of Signs and Wonders, False as well as True, and the Cheats of the Former.
structure_content.summary: This chapter examines how the Devil mimicked divine inspirations and miracles through false prophets and deceptive wonders to gain influence. It contrasts true divine acts with diabolical illusions and human trickery, highlighting the difficulty in distinguishing between them and the danger of falling prey to such deceptions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. VI. Of who were the first Practitioners of Magick, as a Diabolical Art, and how it was handed on to the Egyptians and Phoenicians, where it was first openly encouraged.
structure_content.summary: The book traces the historical lineage of diabolical magic, asserting that its roots in the 'Post-diluvean Ages' can be found in nations like Egypt and Phoenicia, where it gained early public acceptance. It posits that the Devil strategically used human agents to propagate his influence.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. VII. Of the Practice and Progress of Magick, as it is now explain'd to be a Diabolical Art, how it spread it self in the World, and by what Degrees it grew up to the Height which it has since arrived to.
structure_content.summary: This section details the spread and refinement of diabolical magic as an 'Art.' It describes how the Devil, through agents like priests and cunning men, established idolatrous worship and exploited human credulity, leading to increasingly sophisticated forms of deception and control across various cultures.

structure_content.chapter_title: PART II. INTRODUCTION. Of the Black Art it self; what it really is, why there are several differing Practices of it in the several Parts of the World, and what is contained in it in General.
structure_content.summary: The introduction to Part II defines 'Black Art' as a general term for all forms of correspondence between mankind and the Devil. It categorizes these practices, including divination, enchantment, witchcraft, sorcery, and necromancy, and promises to elaborate on their varying manifestations globally.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. I. Of Modern Magick, or the Black Art as now in its Practice and Perfection.
structure_content.summary: This chapter describes modern 'Black Art' as a blend of human cunning and diabolical influence. It highlights how practitioners often operate by trickery, exploiting popular superstition, and even claiming to outwit the Devil, effectively making 'him' their servant through various 'engines' and 'machines' of deception.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. II. The Scene chang'd; That as the Devil acted at First with his Black Art without the Magicians, so the Magicians seem to carry it on now without the Devil.
structure_content.summary: The author argues that modern magicians, through their enhanced 'Craft and Subtilty,' often carry out 'Black Art' independently, making it seem as if the Devil himself is no longer the primary agent. This implies a reversal of roles, where human cunning has become so advanced that it parallels or even surpasses direct demonic intervention.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. III. Of the present Pretences of the Magicians: How they defend themselves; and some Examples of their Practice.
structure_content.summary: This part examines the claims of modern magicians, who assert that they deal with 'good Spirits' rather than the Devil. The author critically analyzes these defenses, presenting examples of cunning men and doctors who use elaborate schemes, figures, and 'hard Words' to deceive clients and maintain their reputation, often for personal gain.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. IV. Of the Doctrine of Spirits as it is understood by the Magicians; How far it may be supposed there may be an Intercourse with Superior Beings, without any Familiarity with the Devil, or evil Spirits; with a Transition to the present Times.
structure_content.summary: The chapter discusses the magicians' doctrine of spirits, questioning the possibility of intercourse with 'Superior Beings' without involving evil spirits. Through a dialogue, the author explores the concept of an 'invisible World' and the nature of spirits, often concluding that what magicians claim to be good spirits are either human delusion or thinly veiled demonic influence.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. V. Of the Magick of the present Time, as it stands strip'd in the last Chapter, from all the Pretences of the Magicians, and the Delusions of Hell; of what Length it has gone, or is like to go, in deluding Mankind; what the Magicians can do, and that they really have now no Converse with the Devil at all: So that the Art being at an End, the History comes to an End of course.
structure_content.summary: This section argues that current 'Magick' is largely human fraud and psychological manipulation. It uses an extended anecdote about a 'Cunning Man' to illustrate how practitioners exploit human fears and desires, demonstrating that their 'magic' is based on trickery rather than genuine supernatural power or direct interaction with the Devil, whose 'Art is at an End' in this form.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. VI. Of raising the Devil by Magical Operations; whether the Magicians really have such a Power or no, and if they have, whether it is perform'd as an Art, and by the Consequence of Magical Experiments, or whether it is by Concert and mutual Consent, between Satan and the Magicians.
structure_content.summary: This chapter investigates the concept of 'raising the Devil,' arguing that such an act is nonsensical as the Devil is not 'raised' but rather already 'above' in the airy regions. It proposes that if such appearances occur, they are either through voluntary consent and agreement between the Devil and his agents or entirely through human deception.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chap. VII. Seeing, as the Magicians pretend, they do not Deal with the Devil, or raise the Devil; Who it is they do Deal with, how their Correspondence is managed, and why do they Deal with Good Spirits, by Conjurings and the Black Art?
structure_content.summary: The final chapter directly challenges magicians' claims of dealing with 'good spirits.' It argues that if these spirits were truly beneficent, they wouldn't require 'conjurations' or 'hard Words.' The author concludes that such practices, due to their scandalous nature and the methods employed, are either entirely human fraud or involve evil spirits disguised as good ones, confirming their alignment with the 'Black Art'.

key_concepts.definition: Originally referred to the wisdom, knowledge, and philosophical/astronomical studies of 'wise men' or 'Magi,' who could interpret omens, dreams, and natural phenomena. These were often respected figures, sometimes kings, contributing to public good through their understanding of Nature.

Refers to degenerate practices involving sorcerers, wizards, dealing with the Devil, enchantments, conjurations, and evil spirits. It is primarily characterized by malicious intent, deception, and personal gain, explicitly distinguished from the ancient, honorable 'Magick'.

The term is used with two distinct meanings: (1) In ancient times, 'wise men' or 'Magi' who were learned in natural philosophy and astronomy. (2) In later times, practitioners of the 'Black Art,' including sorcerers, wizards, and those who claim to deal with the Devil or spirits.

The primary entity behind 'Black Art' practices. The author portrays the Devil as a cunning, political agent whose aim is to 'damn Mankind' by making them 'Rebels' through subtle deceptions (dreams, false visions, mimicry of divine acts) rather than overt force. He leverages human weakness and desire for power or knowledge.

The act of foretelling events, interpreting dreams, telling fortunes, and resolving difficulties, often by studying celestial influences, or through various 'Legerdemain Tricks' and 'Charms.' In the 'Black Art,' it's attributed to either human cunning or diabolical aid.

Practices performed through the 'immediate Agency and Assistance of the evil Spirit,' involving specific 'agreed Gestures and Noises, certain barbarous Names and Words,' and figures/circles to achieve a 'wonderful thing' or influence events.

The 'blackest part of the Black Art,' involving a 'Power received immediately from the Devil to do Mischief,' gratifying negative passions like rage, envy, and malice. It includes persons agitated by evil spirits, flying in the air, and causing harm through spells and curses.

Magical figures 'graved upon Stones or Metals,' corresponding to celestial signs, constellations, or planets. They are attributed with 'marvellous Effects' for various purposes like preserving from stones, securing against animal wounds, or granting success in love, honour, or gaming.

Specific words, gestures, or objects used to influence or cure. In the context of the 'Black Art,' these are often employed by 'Charmers' who claim to converse with 'good Spirits' to stop bleeding, cure cattle, or prevent theft, but which the author implies are either superstitious belief or subtle deception.

Entities believed by some (and claimed by magicians) to assist mankind without diabolical means. The author is skeptical, suggesting that what is attributed to good spirits is often the Devil's work, human self-deception, or merely natural phenomena misunderstood. True communication with such beings is presented as rare and divinely ordained, not achieved through 'Magick'.

practical_system.description: The author's intent is not to provide a practical manual for magic, but rather a historical and critical examination of what people believed to be magic, especially 'Black Art.' The 'system' described is less a method for the reader to follow and more an expos√© of the perceived mechanisms of diabolical influence and human charlatanism. The author views diabolical magic as largely a combination of human 'craft and cunning,' often leveraging 'dreams, apparitions' and 'ingenious contrivances' to deceive, or direct intervention by the Devil when advantageous to him. He argues that modern practitioners mostly rely on 'Juggling and Trick' and 'fraud,' with any genuine supernatural elements being from the Devil's voluntary assistance, not forced by art.
tools: Rods/Staves (used by Egyptian magicians for transformations)
Circles & Figures (drawn on the ground for conjurations or for effect by 'Cunning Men')
Paper & Pen/Ink (used by 'Cunning Men' to record client details and make figures)
Magical Pictures (mentioned as seen in practitioners' homes, possibly for atmosphere or illusion)
Candles (used in ritual settings for ambiance or symbolic effect)
Long white Wand (used by figures in ritual descriptions, possibly as a ceremonial implement)
Books of Magic/Curious Arts (mentioned as containing spells and methods, sometimes burned by converts)
Talismans (engraved figures on stone or metal, often with 'Superstitious Words' or 'Names of unknown Angels' for specific effects)
Brass Kettle or Warming-pan (used to create noise, metaphorically 'hiving bees' or raising spirits by sound)
rituals: Divination (interpreting dreams, omens, celestial influences, reading palms, faces, moles)
Inchantment (using specific gestures, noises, barbarous names and words, drawing circles and figures)
Witchcraft (agitating by evil spirits, causing mischief, setting spells)
Sorcery (a general term for diabolical dealings)
Dealing with Familiar Spirits (cultivating a regular 'Correspondence' with the Devil or his agents)
Raising the Devil (summoning a specific entity by agreed terms, signals, names, or actions, often at particular times/places)
Charming (using words or objects for influence, cure, or protection, e.g., for stopping bleeding or guarding gardens)

relevant_quotes.text: The World has perhaps been imposed upon in nothing more than in their Notions of this dark Practice, as well its antient as its modern State.

In the first Ages they were Wise Men; in the middle Age, Madmen; in these latter Ages, Cunning Men: In the earliest Time they were Honest; in the middle Time, Rogues; in these last Times, Fools: At first they dealt with Nature; then with the Devil; and now not with the Devil, or with Nature either.
The Word Magus, from whence the Words Magick and Magician are derived, is a Persian or perhaps Chaldean Term, used originally to signify a Student in Divinity, a Man conversant in divine Studies...

Thus while Magick is the Wisdom of Nature, and the Magicians of those Ages were the wisest and best of Men; the Magicians of our times, and of this new kind, improve from nothing, begin with the vilest of Ignorance, and proceed to the vilest of Wickedness, till they come to be the most Diabolical Creatures in the World.
The Devil's Business, and all his Aim, is not to destroy, but to damn Mankind; not to cut him off, and put his Maker to the trouble of a new Creation, but to make him a Rebel, like himself...

The brief Definition of what we call the Black Art, that is to say, as I would have it be understood in the rest of my Discourse, is, that it is a new general Term for all the Branches of that Correspondence which Mankind has maintained, or does, or can carry on, between himself and the Devil.

But to hold you no longer upon settling Preliminaries, the Point in hand is, Can the Magicians who we are now speaking of, raise the Devil, or can they not? Can the Magick Art perform this high Operation, is it in the reach of the Profession, and is Satan subjected to it? is he obliged to come when...

critical_analysis.relevance: This book is highly relevant for understanding the historical perception and evolution of magic and occult practices in the early 18th century, particularly within a Christian-dominated intellectual landscape. It reflects a shift from viewing 'ancient Magick' as natural philosophy to condemning 'Black Art' as diabolical. The author's detailed exploration of societal beliefs, skepticism, and the purported mechanisms of demonic interaction offers valuable insight into how such practices were conceptualized and rationalized (or de-rationalized) during this period. It also highlights the intertwining of religious authority, popular superstition, and nascent scientific inquiry in shaping views on the occult. The book can be seen as an effort to demystify (or re-classify as evil) practices that were once considered legitimate wisdom, placing them firmly within the domain of the Devil and human deception.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The book is targeted at an educated, potentially skeptical, but still religiously inclined audience interested in the history and nature of 'Magick' and the 'Black Art.' The author uses a scholarly, argumentative tone, frequently referencing historical figures, biblical texts, and philosophical concepts. It seems intended for those who might be intrigued by occult phenomena but are also concerned with its moral and theological implications, aiming to guide them towards a 'correct' (i.e., Christian) understanding that attributes malicious magic to the Devil and good actions to God or natural causes, while exposing charlatanism.
